metadata.title: Multi-objective spatial optimization to balance trade-offs between farmland bird diversity and potential agricultural net returns

data_sources.source_name: EU Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS)
data_sources.description: Plot-level data on agricultural parameters for the years 2017, 2018, and 2019. Used to derive cropland area, field sizes, crops grown, average distances of all fields of a farm relative to each other, and whether a farm was managed for organic or conventional agriculture.
data_sources.access_conditions: Not publicly available

data_sources.source_name: Remote sensing-based crop-type maps by Blickensdörfer et al. (2022)
data_sources.description: Used to quantify woody features with a spatial resolution of 10 m. These maps contain a woody features class from which proportions of all kinds of woody features (e.g., tree groups, hedgerows, small woods) in the agricultural landscapes for the years 2017 to 2019 were derived.
data_sources.access_conditions: Not publicly available

data_sources.source_name: Common Breeding Bird Monitoring Scheme of Germany (CBBS)
data_sources.description: Data used to assess avian biodiversity. Volunteer observers survey breeding birds annually on up to 1800 plots across Germany. Data filtered for the years 2017, 2018, and 2019 for approximately 200 survey plots situated in Brandenburg.
data_sources.access_conditions: Not publicly available

metadata.title: Experimental evidence of bargaining power in agricultural land markets

data_sources.description: The study conducted an economic experiment to simulate bargaining processes in the land rental market. Participants, who were either tenants or landowners, were asked to negotiate rental rates for hypothetical parcels of land. The experiment aimed to derive reservation utilities of both parties, reflecting their outside options and bargaining power. The data collected included rental rate offers and acceptance thresholds, with participants incentivized through vouchers based on negotiation outcomes.
data_sources.access_conditions: Data collected through a controlled experiment, not publicly accessible

assessment.findability_reason: The data is not publicly accessible and was collected specifically for the study.

assessment.reusability_reason: Data is not reusable due to access restrictions and lack of public availability.

metadata.title: Farm growth and land concentration

data_sources.description: The study uses data from the Integrated Administrative Control System (IACS) for Brandenburg, Germany, covering the years 2005 to 2017. This dataset includes all plots registered to receive European subsidies, based on a geo-referenced land parcel identification system. Each plot is associated with a farm registration number, indicating the farm operating the plot, regardless of the farmstead's location or whether the land is owned or rented. The dataset allows for a precise and spatially explicit analysis of farm activities, enabling the tracking of farm size development over time and the measurement of agricultural land concentration. The data shows that about half of the land transactions occur beyond municipality borders, highlighting the importance of defining the relevant market. The dataset reports a decrease in total agricultural area and the number of farms, alongside an increase in average farm size. It also records changes in farm registration numbers, indicating land transactions. The IACS data is used to derive concentration indicators and assess the impact of land market competition on farm expansion behavior.
data_sources.access_conditions: access granted by the Ministry for Agriculture, Environment and Climate Protection (MLUK) Brandenburg

assessment.findability_reason: The dataset is well-documented within the publication, but access is restricted and requires permission from a governmental body.
assessment.accessibility_reason: Access to the dataset is restricted and requires permission from the Ministry for Agriculture, Environment and Climate Protection (MLUK) Brandenburg.
assessment.interoperability_reason: The dataset is geo-referenced, which aids in spatial analysis, but lacks detailed metadata standards and semantic vocabularies.
assessment.reusability_reason: The dataset is detailed and specific to the study region, but its restricted access and lack of detailed metadata limit broader reusability.

metadata.title: Measuring liquidity in agricultural land markets

data_sources.source_name: Oberer Gutachterausschuss für Grundstückswerte in Niedersachsen
data_sources.description: The dataset consists of nearly all sale transactions of arable land in Lower Saxony between 1990 and 2018. It includes 72,547 sale transactions with details such as price, sold area, seller information, date of transaction, and allocation of the plot to a county. The data is used to analyze the spatial and temporal variability of land market liquidity in Lower Saxony, focusing on volume-based and time-based measures.

metadata.title: Revisiting the relationship between land price and parcel size in agriculture

data_sources.source_name: Committee of Land Valuation Experts (Gutachterausschuss für Grundstückswerte in Sachsen-Anhalt)
data_sources.description: The dataset includes all agricultural land transactions in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany, from 1994 to 2017. It contains information on the price, size, soil quality, location, and type (arable land or grassland) of the transacted plot. Since 2011, information about the buyer (farmer or non-farmer) is also available. The dataset was used to analyze the relationship between land price and parcel size using a nonparametric locally weighted scatterplot smoothing (LOWESS) estimator and a hedonic land price model.
data_sources.access_conditions: provided by the Committee of Land Valuation Experts

metadata.title: Is there a risk of a winner’s curse in farmland auctions?

data_sources.description: The study uses a dataset of 9,754 first-price sealed-bid farmland privatisation auctions conducted in eastern Germany between 2007 and 2020. The data includes information on all bids and the auctioned goods, such as location, lot size, lot type (shares of arable, grassland, and other land), lot composition (number of parcels), and soil quality. Additionally, local experts' appraisals, which remain private to the auctioneer, are used to account for unobserved heterogeneity. These appraisals are based on publicly available results of transactions and auctions of similar lots in the same region during the 12 months prior to the auction. The dataset is used to test the presence of common values in bidders' valuations and the potential for a winner's curse in farmland auctions.
data_sources.access_conditions: Data provided by BVVG and not publicly available

assessment.findability_reason: The data is not publicly available and is provided by BVVG, making it difficult to find without specific access.

metadata.title: Farmland sales under returns and price uncertainty

data_sources.source_name: Committee of Land Valuation Experts in Lower Saxony (Oberer Gutachterausschuss für Grundstückswerte in Niedersachsen, OGA)
data_sources.description: This dataset contains sale transactions of arable land in Lower Saxony between 2005 and 2018. It includes information on the price, size, seller, buyer, date of transaction, and location. The data was used to derive the volume duration, which is the number of days until a specific percentage of land per county was sold. The study focused on 1% volume duration, with robustness checks for 0.5% and 1.5%.

metadata.title: Revisiting the relationship between farmland prices and soil quality
metadata.publisher: Oxford University in association with European Agricultural and Applied Economics Publications Foundation

data_sources.source_name: GENESIS-Database of the German Bundesamt für Statistik
data_sources.description: The dataset contains aggregated farmland price time series from 1991 to 2020 within Germany. Prices are aggregated within soil quality intervals and parcel size intervals, treated as panel units. The dataset has a balanced panel structure with 145 observations and 870 price data points in total. The number of recorded transactions used to aggregate the farmland prices were collected manually from the Statistische Jahrbücher in Germany from 1991 to 2020. The minimum number of transactions recorded per SQI interval is 3,929, and the maximum is 15,819. The dataset helps maintain soil quality constant within the defined interval while depicting the farmland price development over time. Other variables are not available due to the levels of data aggregation, and regional prices are not captured.
data_sources.access_conditions: Free access

assessment.findability_reason: The dataset is publicly available and easily accessible through the GENESIS database of the Statistical Office of Germany.
assessment.accessibility_reason: The dataset is freely accessible without any restrictions.
assessment.interoperability_reason: The dataset is in a time series format, which is standard but lacks detailed metadata and semantic vocabularies.
assessment.reusability_reason: The dataset is comprehensive for the study's purpose but lacks additional variables that could enhance its applicability for other research contexts.

metadata.title: Market Power in Agricultural Land Markets: Concepts and Empirical Challenges

data_sources.description: The study uses land sales transaction data from local committees of land valuation experts in Brandenburg, Germany, covering the years 2007 to 2018. This dataset includes transaction prices, lot sizes, soil quality, type of land use (arable land or grassland), and anonymized information about buyer and seller types. The data is used to analyze the relationship between land use concentration and farmland prices, revealing a negative relationship that suggests market power on the buyer side.
data_sources.access_conditions: Data is available from local committees of land valuation experts, but access may be restricted due to privacy concerns.

metadata.title: Predator or prey? Effects of farm growth on neighbouring farms
metadata.publisher: John Wiley & Sons Ltd on behalf of Agricultural Economics Society

data_sources.description: The study uses data from experiments conducted with the business game FarmAgriPoliS, which is based on the AgriPoliS model. This model simulates farms, regional farm populations, and structures, focusing on strategic decisions like farm exit or continuation, investments, and land rentals. The experiments involved 49 students managing pre-specified farms in a simulated environment representing the Altmark region in Germany. The dataset includes 143 experiments across nine scenarios, with data on farm investments, land rentals, farm sizes, financial results, and rents paid.
data_sources.access_conditions: Data was collected during controlled experiments and is not publicly available.

It includes transaction details such as contract date, price, lot characteristics (location, size, soil quality index), and anonymous agent-type information. The data was used to analyze the role of asymmetric information in farmland price formation, focusing on the effects of buyer and seller characteristics on price dispersion.

metadata.title: What Moves the German Land Market? A Decomposition of the Land Rent-Price Ratio

data_sources.description: Land price data from 1975-2016 were extracted from the Statistisches Jahrbuch published by the Statistisches Bundesamt. Prices refer to agricultural land including arable land and grassland. Nominal agricultural land sales prices are available on country and federal state level on an annual basis. Land rental prices are also available at country and federal state level, but only for every second (1975-2007) or third year (after 2007) due to the frequency of the underlying Agricultural census. To conduct an analysis on a yearly basis, rental prices were linearly interpolated. The rental price data reflect prices of running contracts, i.e., they reflect the average of the rent paid for agricultural land during a contract period of several years. Rental price data for newly concluded contracts would have been more suitable for the analysis since they reflect the most recent information about expected productivity of land, but unfortunately, these data are not available for the desired time period. This implies that rental prices in the analysis appear more sluggish than they actually are. To conduct the analysis for Western Germany as a whole, federal state data on land sales and rental prices were used and averaged using the agricultural area of every federal state as weights. Nominal prices were converted into real prices by measuring inflation with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for Germany published by Statistisches Bundesamt.
data_sources.access_conditions: available online

assessment.findability_reason: The data is publicly available and can be accessed online through the Statistisches Bundesamt website.
assessment.accessibility_reason: The data is freely accessible without any restrictions.
assessment.interoperability_reason: The data is available in a standard format but may require additional processing for integration with other datasets.
assessment.reusability_reason: The data is reusable for similar analyses, although the interpolation of rental prices may affect its applicability for certain studies.

metadata.title: On the effectiveness of restricted tendering as a form of policy intervention on agricultural land markets

data_sources.description: The dataset consists of over 12,000 first-price-sealed-bid auctions of agricultural land conducted by BVVG in Eastern Germany between 2005 and 2019. The data includes information on the winning bid, the total number of bidders, the exact date of the auction, the location, plot-specific land characteristics including a soil quality index, the lot size, the number of land parcels, and the type of use (arable land versus pasture), as well as the type of tender (open versus restricted). The data was used to analyze the effectiveness of restricted tendering procedures in allowing structurally disadvantaged groups to purchase agricultural land at lower prices. The study found that restricted tendering did not achieve its intended purpose of lowering purchase prices, although it did reduce the number of bidders.
data_sources.access_conditions: provided by BVVG

metadata.publisher: Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group

data_sources.description: The dataset includes information on arable land auctions conducted by the BVVG in eastern German states from 2005 to 2019. It contains details on auction packages (lots), which may include one or more plots, and for each sale transaction, the date, number of bidders, and all bids are recorded. Additionally, information on plot size, number of plots, and soil quality is provided. The dataset was used to analyze the potential for increasing revenues through optimal reserve prices in land auctions.

metadata.title: Eco-efficiency in the agricultural landscape of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany

data_sources.description: The study used spatially explicit land cover data from the Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS) to describe landscape composition and configuration. The data was used to define four ecosystem function indicators: the Shannon diversity index, edge density, and shares of grassland and ecological focus areas. The IACS data provided spatially explicit information at the plot level of registered plots above the minimum eligible size of 0.3 ha, including location, shape, land use, crop choice, and ecological focus areas.
data_sources.access_conditions: Available through the EU’s Common Agricultural Policy (CAP)

data_sources.description: Standardized farmland values were used to indicate the economic output of the landscape. These values are provided by local land valuation expert committees and refer to a standardized lot reflecting local characteristics such as soil quality and lot sizes. The values are based on land transactions in the same land value zone in the two years prior to the reporting year, adjusted for local average conditions and a rectangular shape.
data_sources.access_conditions: Available through local land valuation expert committees

metadata.title: Public Preferences for Pasture Landscapes and the Role of Scale Heterogeneity

data_sources.description: The study revisits public preferences for pasture landscapes in Germany, focusing on the presence of livestock in the landscape. It uses a Discrete Choice Experiment (DCE) to assess preferences for different landscape attributes, including the presence and number of dairy livestock, structuredness of the pasture, point landscape elements, linear landscape elements, and cost per household per year. The DCE was part of an online survey conducted in Germany with 475 participants, of which 449 were included in the study sample. The survey ensured representativeness concerning age, household income, federal state of residence, and size of the place of residence. The data was collected by an online-sampling company in September and October of 2017.
data_sources.access_conditions: Not specified
